comments.text:
Ever seen an ultrasound? Scientists do basically the same thin with the 
sound waves created by earthquakes to "see" inside the Earth. The rate at 
which waves bounce back or travel through a material gives you very 
dependable data about the material, its composition, viscosity, 
temperature, etc. The size and shape of the Earths magnetosphere are 
directly proportional to the material, temperature and rotation of the 
Earths core. There are many ways to glean facts without "seeing" something. 
If you hear a plane flying above the clouds but cannot "see" it, does it 
not exist? Your ears pick up the volume, and pitch, and with that 
information, your brain forms a very accurate representation of the size 
and altitude of the plane you can not "see". In fact the modulation of the 
sound will tell you if it is a jet, a prop plane, or a helicopter. Imagine 
how aggravating it would be to tell a friend "I hear a helicopter", but 
your friend says (and believes) "I don't see it, so it cannot be there, you 
are full of shit!" Now imagine the entire scientific community dealing with 
the religiously blind, the young earthers, and those that believe the moon 
landings were faked....

I discussed the centre of the Earth for illustrative purposes. It's

obvious that being at the centre of the earth results in balanced 
gravitational forces (effective weightlessness). My only point was that 
since descending 7.5 miles brings you 7.5 miles closer to the place where 
you will be weightless, it stands to reason that you will decrease and not 
increase the effects of gravity (all other things being equal).

comments.text:
+naesdrareb I don't know enough about Earth's geology and changes in 
density to demonstrate that's wrong, but that doesn't seem right. Remember, 
the gravitational force one body exerts on another depends on both mass and 
proximity. As you descend, you get closer to the core (which is denser), 
but you also have mass above you providing a counteracting force.

Think of it this way: If you were right in the middle of the Earth, you'd 
be pulled equally in all directions and be effectively weightless. Right? 
That's not going to happen all at once, you're going to gradually move from 
Earth's surface gravity to that weightless state as you descend. Therefore, 
as you go down, the gravitational pull you feel will (on average) decrease, 
not increase.

Depending on how much denser the core of the Earth is than the mantle, 
maybe it may be possible that the decreased distance to the core will (for 
a time) increase gravity's pull faster than the mantle you've passed 
decreases it -- but I doubt it.

Regardless, 12km is definitely too short a distance for the change to 
matter. Your own experience probably proves this... ever travelled a long 
distance on a big airliner? They fly about 12km up. How much lighter did 
you feel? If you extend this further, astronauts in orbit on the ISS 400km 
up experience roughly 90% of the gravity we do on Earth. Even if the top 
and bottom of this borehole experienced that large of a difference in 
gravitational pull, that only averages out to a 5% difference in drop 
time... I'm sure the other factors we've discussed add up to a larger 
margin of error than that.
comments.author: Jon

comments.text:
+Xuncu I think your estimates a long way on the low side... both 
theoretically and practically.

A quick google search told me that a nickel's terminal velocity is about 32 
mph. Over these distances, the time to acceleration is going to be within 
our margin of error, so we won't worry about it. The hole is 7.5 miles 
deep. So, 7.5 miles / 32 mph * 60 minutes = 14.06 minutes to fall. 

That's at surface level atmosphere.

I don't think currents are something we need to account for. If there's air 
rising, there's going to be an equal amount of air going down... it's not 
as if there's a source of air at the bottom. How these currents will work 
isn't predictable, but I think it's safe to say they'll roughly balance out 
over 7.5 miles.

Air pressure's harder to adjust for. I'm working off tables, because I 
don't have the formulas to hand, but going from 0f to 300f reduces 
atmospheric pressure by about 40%. Going from 10,000ft to sea level creates 
about the same change in pressure. From the surface to the bottom of this 
hole is 4 times that change in altitude... so I think it's safe to assume 
that the air will be denser rather than less dense -- slowing it more. I'm 
sure someone smarter than me could do a reasonable job of estimating this.

The biggest problem, however, is the coriolis effect. Anything you drop 
down that hole is going to hit the side a long way before it reaches the 
bottom. Depending on how smooth the sides are, it may well get stuck. Even 
if it doesn't, I don't think anyone would claim to be able to make a 
reasonable estimate for how it would bounce (or slide?) along the walls and 
what impact that would have on the average velocity.

I don't think anyone could give an accurate answer to this without 
experimentation. But, unless I've made a dumb error in my arithmetic, I 
think it's safe to say "at least 14 minutes".
comments.author: Jon

comments.text:
The fact that it shows (among others) the reason why many fossiles are not 
found, is because they have moved below the surface due to tectonic plate 
movement. Also interesting to see that things that have been scientifically 
proven above, also work the same at high depth (we already knew that you 
could 'leak' water from sediment when putting it under high pressure). 
Another thing is: The hole can be drilled to 12.2 KM, but the plates still 
move. I guess they took a place that was most unlikely to move (especially 
in a short period of 24 years) too much to jeopardize the stability of the 
'well' (imagine the fact that the highest we can build with structure 
integrity intact with metal is around 1km (Dubai building 829m, still 
almost 200meters short). Imagine doing these drillings in a location where 
a vaultline is. Within 24 years, there is most likely to be a tremor 
nihilating all effort done on the project. It might even be, added to  the 
give reason, another reason why the drill was stopped. In all, there are 
many interesting things in the video, from many perspectives (even the date 
they starte drilling and any theories about why they drilled). The video is 
no indepth story, but you can't leave out parts of the already thin 
accummulation of facts. 'oh, lets forget about the fossiles (well 
documented and dated by several dating mechanisms), because that might not 
fall with our indoctrinated ideas.

top_comment.text:
As fascinating as science may be, most of it is theoretical. Since we have 
never gone deeper than 12 km into the earth, there is no way to KNOW 
ANYTHING about the earth's core. It's just a theory!

There are many such theories, such as, the theory of evolution and big bang 
theory, for instance. Let's not forget the theory of carbon dating, which 
seems to be taken as fact, when all the evidence points to it's utter 
unreliability. Just because someone with a degree and skills in 
mathematical wizardry says something, does not make it true.

I like this SciShow guy, but his mainstream science bias is obvious. Why 
doesn't he use his substantial brain to apply the scientific method to 
science itself? Do a show on; "Is science really scientific?"

I'm no scientist but, I do have a brain and from what I can tell, science 
depends on a belief that there could not possibly be any truth to the Bible 
and that there could not possibly be a Creator. If that's your starting 
point, how could you ever find truth? Napoleon Bonaparte once said, "People 
will believe anything unless it comes from the Bible." Lots of people use 
science to prove the Bible wrong, but is that really science? Shouldn't 
science start with no assumptions with an open mind? There is a proverb 
that goes something like this, "A man who dismisses a matter before hearing 
is foolish."

I can't declare the Bible to be true. But I can declare that much of the 
science we are fed in the mainstream is based on theoretical assumptions. 
Which is to say, one must believe the assumptions first, or the science 
makes no sense. It's more like a religion than a search for knowledge.

At least with the Bible we have archaeological and historical evidence 
(more and more of it every day) attesting to the Bible as a valuable 
historic account of life on this planet. It can also be demonstrated that 
the Bible has accurately predicted future events. That in itself is cause 
for serious inquiry!

I would not have said these things 5 years ago, but having taken the Bible 
with an open mind for more than half a decade now, I have come to change my 
opinion about the nature of our reality. I still don't know what to believe 
but, I am no longer interested in theories. In fact, it sure looks like we 
have had the truth hidden from us by clever use of theoretical science. So, 
I can no longer blindly believe mainstream propaganda; that includes 
science and history, not to mention the news media!﻿

comments.text:
+Adino1 The accuracy is in the result of the model, because all models are 
still an approximation of physical action, even thermonuclear detonation 
simulations, despite going down into individual subatomic interactions 
chewing up weeks of supercomputer time, are approximations, albeit 
stunningly accurate ones that show highly reliable general trends. The 
whole point of modelling is to achieve the same results from the model as 
you would from a hard data either from observation or experimentation. 
That's the first step, if there are holes in the results matching up, you 
can refine the algorithm over time and improve its accuracy. That's what 
gives science its predictive power. Not absolute and unimpeachable 
knowledge, because no such thing exists.

comments.author: Adino1

comments.text:
+Adino1 There's a significant difference between predicting transitional 
layers in rock formations where there can be a significant degree of 
uncertainty, and understand the overall internal structure of the planet. 
The geomagnetic field surrounding the planet physically dictates a 
geomagnetic dynamo which has a limited number of natural configurations, 
and when narrowed down with geophysics studying seismic wave data, we have 
an extremely clear picture of what's happening inside the planet.

+Nick 'Dutchie' Hi Nick, I was just making a comment as neutral as 
possible, sorry if it sounded agressive or whatever. Just laying down some 
kinda realistic figures for others to understand that it's unrealistic.

It doesn't address your original question though: the main problem is : 
deepest mines today go as deep as approx. 1km. Here, we are talking 12 km, 
and the limiting factor is not the depth itself (it could be 5 or 20km, it 
wouldn't matter), but the environment conditions that you find at such 
depth: pressure & more importantly temperature. It doesn't matter if you 
use a drilling head or an excavator truck: these 2 parameters remain the 
same and make it impossible to keep digging with available techniques.

comments.text:
+Nick 'Dutchie' When you dig holes, you're trying to create a space within 
the ground, and the dirt that was originally there has to go somewhere. A 
flipped-pyramid-shaped hole would be creating a lot of empty space, and 
that's a lot of dirt to displace.

For the water thing, it's because water cannot be compressed, so the 
surrounding soil would hold. That is unless the water gets absorbed, which 
is unlikely since the liquid oil was originally there. And even if it does, 
only small amount of water would.

Also, keep up the learning!

captions.text:
Deep in western Russia, the frigid desert
contains the remnants of one of the most ambitious

scientific experiments ever performed. It's
a ruin now, a wasteland of jagged metal and
crumbling concrete.

If you search around long enough, you will
find a rusted disc, bolted to the earth. So

unassuming that you might even try to pick
it up. But you won't be able to.

It's the welded-shut cap of a borehole that
plummets more than twelve kilometers into

the earth, deeper than the deepest depths
of the ocean. It's the deepest hole on earth.

It's called the Kola Superdeep Borehole, and
its existence has nothing to do with petroleum

exploration. Rather, when drilling began in
1970, Soviet scientists hoped to eventually

drill down to fifteen thousand meters in order
to gain a better understanding of the nature

of the Earth's crust. Because the truth is,
we know less about what's under our feet than
what's on the other side of the solar system.

They drilled on and off for twenty-four years,
and though they didn't quite reach their goal

when work came to a halt in 1994, the engineers
had reached a record depth: 12,262 meters,
a record that still stands today.

Two decades later, the Kola Borehole remains
a remarkable technological and scientific

acheivement. To drill it, engineers devised
a new method by which only the drill bit at

the end of the shaft was rotated, the lubricant,
in this case, pressurized drilling mud, was

pumped down through a custom drill bit, allowing
it to spin. Instruments had to be invented

to take measurements at the bottom of the
hole.

What did we learn by drilling a third of the
way through the Baltic continental crust?

For one, there's water down there, at depths
scientists didn't believe water could be found.

They suspect that the water formed from hydrogen
and oxygen that were squeezed out of rock

crystals due to crazy high levels of pressure
that far down.

Unlike groundwater, this water originated
from the rock minerals themselves. Never before

had this been observed. Also surpising, how
about microscopic fossils discovered by Russians
at depths of up to 6.7 kilometers?

Researchers catalogued twenty-four species
of single-cell plankton microfossils over

the course of the project, and they weren't
found in the kinds of deposits we're used
to finding them, like limestone and silica.

These were covered by organic carbon and nitrogen
compounds, preserved thanks to those high

pressures and high temperatures so far below
the surface. As for those temperatures, by

the time the engineers broke through the twelve
kilometer mark, where rock samples were dated

at 2.7 billion years old, the heat became
a major issue.

Researchers thought the temperature of the
rocks would be about 100 degrees Celsius.

What they found were temperatures in excess
of 180 degrees. It was this heat that caused

the drilling to come to a stop. Engineers
described the rocks at 12 kilometers as acting
more like plastic than rock.

Of course, as astonishing as this project
was, the Kola Superdeep Borehole only made

it through a tiny fraction of the Earth's
layers. 12 kilometers is three times as deep

as humans have ever gone, but the eath's mantle
desn't even begin until about 35 kilometers
below the surface.

The mantle then continues for another twenty-eight
hundred kilometers; the center of the inner

core: more than sixty-three hundred kilometers
below the surface.

Put another way, this borehole which took
24 years to drill, made it roughly 0.002 percent

of the way to the middle of the Earth. It's
a big planet, you guys.

Thank you for watching this SciShow Dose,
especially to our Subbable subscribers. To

learn how you can support us, just go to subbable.com
to learn more. And be sure to check out our

new channel, SciShow Space, for the latest
in space news, and weekly forays into the
fascinating depths of the cosmos.

If you have any questions, you can find us
on Facebook and Twitter, and as always, in

the comments below, and if you want to keep

and subscribe.

title: The Deepest Hole in the World, And What We've Learned From It
